newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: NZ dlr surges to higher close on offshore buying.
newsitem.headline: NZ dlr surges to higher close on offshore buying.

text.p: The New Zealand dollar surged higher on Monday, posting fresh eight-year highs in the process and closing around 71 U.S. cents.
"The offshore buying is just getting stronger and stronger and it's just going to push the currency higher and higher," a chief dealer said.
The Kiwi closed at 0430 GMT at US$0.7096/03 and at 67.71 on its Trade-Weighted Index, up from 0.7048/55 and 67.30 at the opening.
"We heard there was some buying of Kiwi against the yen out of Japan today and really, a bit like the old 07/98 bond, there's just a lack of supply at the moment," the chief dealer said.
At 79.92/07, the Kiwi was at a five-year high against the yen.
"We're hearing there's going to be more interest out of Japan to buy Kiwi over the coming week, so personally, I think we might get into the mid-0.7100s pretty easily this week," the dealer said.
He said New Zealand's high real interest rates continued to attract offshore investors.
"At the end of the day, as long as the Reserve Bank continues to hold interest rates at these levels, the Kiwi will just keep going higher and higher.
"The Reserve Bank knows this, they just deliberately want the currency higher and higher to flatten out inflation."
The Kiwi was seen trading a 0.7070-7120 range overnight.
